Graphical abstract In the present work, a strategy for the incorporation of nitrogen-rich units to an unsaturated Cr-based MOF, MIL-100-Cr, is reported. Based on this strategy, various cyanide functional groups (diamino malononitrile, 1,3-phenylene diacetonitrile, and malononitrile) were incorporated into the framework and utilized as exceptional catalysts in the carbon dioxide fixation under mild, solvent, and co-catalyst free conditions. This is the first report on the application of cyano-bifunctional frameworks in cycloaddition reaction. The contemporaneous presence of accessible Lewis acid sites and pendent cyanide groups results in highly striking conversion and TON even for bulky and large substrates. High tendency and strong interaction of cyanide groups with CO2 cause a synergetic effect in the performance of the catalysts. The role of different cyanide groups applied in this work has also been studied. The reaction wouldn’t proceed in the presence of pristine MOF without co-catalyst addition. Keywords Metal organic framework CO2 fixation Co-catalyst free Solvent free Superior catalyst Cyanide functional group 1 Introduction In the last few decades, nanoporous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) which are considered innovative materials, have been intensively developed owing to their unique characteristics such as structural versatility, high porosity, and surface area, large pore apertures, and tunable composition making them highly promising materials for various applications such as gas storage and separation, adsorption, drug delivery, sensing, and catalysis [1–4]. These materials are constructed from metal ion clusters joined by polyfunctional organic linkers [5]. The adjustable structure of MOFs stems from their decorative moieties, can lead to the improvement of their properties by incorporation of functional groups to either organic linkers or coordinatively unsaturated metal sites [6]. This enables the design and adjustment of these materials as heterogeneous catalysts in the desired reactions. On the other hand, carbon dioxide (CO2) is a nonflammable abundant anthropogenic greenhouse gas, the rising level of which is in the atmosphere has triggered serious environmental issues including global warming and ocean acidification in recent years [7]. To overcome the on-going problem different carbon capture and storage (CCS) techniques have been applied such as photochemical or electrochemical reduction of CO2 among which the formation of cyclic carbonates from epoxides is the most promising and intensively studied technique [8–10]. The product of this chemical transformation can be utilized for various valuable applications such as the synthesis of pharmaceutical compounds, precursors for polycarbonate synthesis, and fine chemical industries. Since the chemical fixation of CO2 into cyclic carbonates is an intrinsic thermodynamically stable reaction, the progress of the reaction requires a powerful nucleophile as well as harsh reaction conditions (long reaction time, high temperature, and pressure) [11]. Due to this issue, carbon dioxide fixation reactions have been accomplished over various active catalysts such as MOFs, complexes, metal oxides, and ionic liquids [12–14]. With these considerations in mind, attempts were made to eliminate or diminish the aforementioned shortcomings and improve catalytic performance. Given that acidic sites and a basic salt (tetraalkylammonium halide) which played the co-catalyst role are needed for this chemical transformation, in this work, it was attempted to remove the co-catalyst addition and incorporate the co-catalyst within the structure of MOF. Since various nitrogen-rich units including amine or cyanide functional groups have high tendency and great potential for efficacious adsorption of CO2, modification of MOFs with these groups can enhance the catalytic activity of the structure as well as the removal of co-catalyst addition. Therefore, in continuation of our work on the application of different cyano-functional groups as co-catalysts within the MIL-100-Cr structure, three cyano-functionalized MIL-100-Cr have been designed and synthesized with both acidic and basic sites within the structure (Scheme 1 ). The cyano-functionalized bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts were employed in cycloaddition reactions under relatively mild conditions (low temperature and pressure) without the addition of either solvent or co-catalyst and excellent results were obtained under foregoing conditions. Moreover, a comparison was made between the catalytic efficiency of the prepared cyano-functionalized MOFs in order to evaluate the effect of orientation and steric hindrance of cyanide groups in the structure. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first MOF catalyst containing cyanide functional groups that played the role of removed co-catalyst within the structure. The catalytic properties and reaction mechanism will be discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material and instrumentations Material and instrumentations are illustrated in supplementary material. 2.2 Catalysts synthesis 2.2.1 MIL-100-Cr synthesis (1) Based on the reported procedure [15], MIL-100-Cr was prepared by solvothermal method. In accordance with the synthesis procedure, 1 mL 5 M HF was added to the mixture of 0.5 g (3.28 mmol) of chromium (VI) oxide and 1.06 g (5 mmol) of trimesic acid in deionized water (24 mL). Having been stirred for 15 min at room temperature, the mixture was transferred to a 50 mL stainless steel reactor and heated for 2 days at 220 °C. The green-colored crystals were isolated from the solution by centrifugation and washed with a mixture of acetone and deionized water. The resulting powder was activated at 130 °C for one day in the air. 2.2.2 MIL-100-Cr-DAmalo synthesis (2) Preparation of (2) was carried out by the following procedure. 0.5 g of the activated as-synthesized of (1) was suspended in toluene (20 mL). 0.14 g (1.35 mmol) of diaminomaleononitrile dissolved in a minimum amount of dimethylformamide was mixed with the mentioned solution and the mixture obtained refluxed for 16 h. The obtained solid was washed with ethanol and dried for 3 h at 100 °C. 2.2.3 MIL-100-Cr-PhDA synthesis (3) The synthesis procedure of (3) is slightly different from the aforementioned procedure. For synthesis, 0.56 g of (1) was stirred in 20 mL of toluene and was mixed with a solution containing 0.51 g (3.31 mmol) of 1,3-phenylene diacetonitrile in 20 mL of dichloromethane. Then the resulting mixture was refluxed for 16 h. The obtained precipitate was washed with dichloromethane, dried for 3 h at 100 °C. 2.2.4 MIL-100-Cr-malo synthesis (4) For the synthesis of (4), the same procedure used for (3) was applied with a slight difference. In this method, 0.1 g (1.51 mmol) of malononitrile is used instead of 1,3-phenylene diacetonitrile. 2.3 Cycloaddition of epoxides with carbon dioxide In a typical experiment, 25 mg of the activated catalysts (0.014 mmol cyanide groups) and 20 mmol of epoxides were added to a 25 mL stainless steel reactor. Carbon dioxide was introduced to the mixture up to 1 MPa and stirred at 60 °C for 24 h. After the specified time, the reactor was cooled and the ultimate solution was characterized by gas chromatography. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization The results of IR spectra and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis confirm the successful synthesis and modification of the prepared framework (Figs. S1 and S2, respectively). As observed in the IR spectrum of (1) (Fig. S1a), the bands observed at around 1390 and 1644 cm−1 are related to the symmetric and asymmetric COO stretching vibrations, respectively [16]. The out-of-plane vibration of C ̶ H in the phenyl rings has appeared at 722 and 758 cm-1. The IR spectra of 1, 2, 3, and 4 are represented in Figs. S1a, S1b, S1c, and S1d, respectively. After incorporation of diamino malononitrile to the framework, the CN band becomes manifest at 2225 cm-1 confirming the successful incorporation of the cyanide groups to the framework (Fig. S1b). This band is observed in the same area in the IR spectra of materials 3 and 4 (Figs. S1c and S1d, respectively). The absence of CN stretching vibrations peak at 1640 cm-1 is owing to the overlapping with the asymmetric COO stretching vibration. To Figure out the crystalline nature of the synthesized frameworks, the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique was accomplished and results are exhibited in Fig. S2. The XRD pattern of the synthesized materials revealed the successful synthesis and incorporation of cyano groups into the framework. Furthermore, it can be observed that the structural crystallinity and main diffraction peaks maintain intact upon modification of the framework [15]. To specify the morphology and particle size of the frameworks, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was accomplished. The SEM micrographs of the synthesized materials are depicted in Fig. S3. As observed in Fig. S3, the average particle size of MIL-100-Cr is about 110 nm. Moreover, the structural integrity and morphology of the framework were retained after the incorporation of cyanide groups within the framework. In order to investigate the thermal behavior of the prepared frameworks, thermogravimetric technique (TG) was accomplished and the TG curves are presented in Fig. S4. According to the results, the first weight loss for MIL-100-Cr is observed at about 50−120 °C due to the elimination of coordinated water molecules (Fig. S4). The decomposition of the frameworks occurs at approximately 410 °C, highlighting the high stability of the prepared material. The TG curves for the modified frameworks are similar to those of the pristine MOF. The materials are thermally stable up to 410 °C and the absence of remarkable weight loss before framework destruction confirms the absence of most water molecules and consequently, the successful modification of the framework. XPS analysis was performed to obtain information about the chemical environment of the elements and surface compositions. XPS spectra of 2 are represented in Fig. 1 and Fig. S5. The wide scan spectrum of 2 exhibits remarkable signals indicated the existence of C, O, N, and Cr elements (Fig. S5a). As can be seen in Fig. 1a, the spectra of Cr2p revealed two types of peaks. Strong high peaks ascribed to the bonding energy of Cr2p1/2 and Cr2p3/2 of the framework, observed at 587.8 and 577.7 eV, respectively. Along with these main peaks, two more feeble satellite peaks can be seen at higher binding energy (589.1 and 579.2 eV) which can be attributed to the modified Cr2p1/2 and Cr2p3/2 with diaminomaleonitrile groups, respectively [17]. The N1S high-resolution XPS spectrum of 2 is displayed in Fig. 1b. Two peaks with equal contributions perceived at 401 and 399.8 eV corresponding to the bonding energy of CN and CN, respectively [18]. The aforementioned spectra affirmed the successful incorporation of diaminomaleonitrile groups within the structure. Additionally, the O1S for carboxylic acid ligands of trimesic acid, observed at 533 eV (Fig. S5b). N2 adsorption-desorption technique was carried out to specify pore size distribution, surface area, and porosity of materials, and the textural parameters are displayed in Table 1 . The N2 adsorption-desorption experiments for the synthesized frameworks exhibit reversible type I isotherms (Fig. 2 ). Based on the results, the apparent surface area and pore volume of 1 are 1864 m2/g and 1.01 cm3/g, respectively, whilst the modification of the framework causes a reduction in the quantities of relevant values to 944 m2/g and 0.6 cm3/g, 1144 m2/g and 0.7 cm3/g and 1502 m2/g and 0.9 cm3/g for 2, 3 and 4, respectively. The smaller textural parameters demonstrate the authenticity of the modification of the framework. In order to evaluate the tendency of the prepared materials toward CO2 adsorption, CO2 gas sorption measurement was conducted and the results are illustrated in Fig. 3 . According to the CO2 adsorption curves, the CO2 uptake values for the pristine MOF are about 11 cm3/g and increased up to 37, 32, and 31 cm3/g for 2, 3, and 4, respectively owing to the modification of the framework. Therefore, it can be concluded that 2 has the highest tendency to adsorb CO2, whereas by changing the type of cyanide ligand, this tendency is reduced for 3 and 4, respectively. The potential basic and acidic in the prepared materials were investigated by means of temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments. CO2 and NH3 -TPD profiles of 2 are presented in Fig. 4 . According to the results, the NH3-TPD profile of 2 exhibits a desorption peak at about 500 K. This strong acidic site is related to the presence of uncoordinated metal centers in the framework (Fig. 4a). Moreover, in the CO2-TPD profile of 2, strong basic sites are observed owing to the presence of cyanide functional group within the framework (Fig. 4b). Moreover, the amount of acidic and basic sites of prepared materials are summarized in Table 2 . According to the results, the total amount of NH3 and CO2 adsorption for pristine MOF was estimated to be 1.82 and 0.21 mmol/g, respectively. The metal center and aromatic phenyl rings in 1 are expected to be responsible for acidic and basic sites, respectively. Incorporation of cyanide functional groups to the metal center of the framework caused reduction and enhancement in the amount of acidic and basic sites, respectively. To understand the amount of loading in the modified frameworks, CHN elemental analysis was conducted and the results are exhibited in Table S1. Accordingly, the amounts of cyanide functional group loaded in the modified framework according to the weight percent of nitrogen are 5.87, 8.74, and 3.69 % for materials 2, 3, and 4, respectively. Therefore, CHN analysis also affirmed the successful introduction of cyanide groups within the framework. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the prepared materials MIL-100-Cr was first prepared and modified with different cyanide group to enhance the catalytic activity of the prepared material under mild condition (low pressure and temperature, solvent-free and in the absence of any co-catalyst) for carbon dioxide fixation and comparing the effect of the type of substituent on the progress of the reaction. For this purpose, MIL-100-Cr-DAmalo, MIL-100-Cr-PhDA, and MIL-100-Cr-malo were applied as catalysts 2, 3, and 4 in the cycloaddition of epoxides with CO2 to form cyclic carbonates. Chemical fixation reaction was carried out in the presence of pristine MOF in order to affirm that the incorporated groups play the key role in the reaction progression and the reaction wouldn’t proceed in the presence of the sole framework without co-catalyst addition. The obtained results are represented in Table 3 . Inspired by the results, CO2 fixation reactions are not accomplished without the presence of catalyst (Table 3, entry 1). Moreover, it can be seen that either the lone diaminomaleononitrile or the pristine framework cannot significantly progress the reactions (Table 3, entries 2 and 3). While the introduction of cyanide groups caused the reaction to progress absolutely with the conversion of 100 % (Table 3, entry 4). It is noteworthy that the physical mixture of MIL-100-Cr with diaminomaleononitrile causes slight progress (about 28 %) in the cycloaddition reaction. But recycling and sequestration are the main problems that we encounter in the reaction system while using the physical mixture. Although, the reaction proceeds slightly in this case. 3.3 Chemical fixation of carbon dioxide with epoxides Epichlorohydrin (ECH) was applied as a model substrate in the chemical fixation of carbon dioxide with epoxide owing to its lack of volatility. The reaction conditions (time, pressure, amount of catalyst, and temperature) were optimized and the obtained results are displayed in Figs. S6, S7, S8, and S9, respectively. It can be observed that epichlorohydrin produced epichlorohydrin carbonate (ECHC) as the lone product with the excellent conversion of 100 % using 25 mg of catalyst 2 (0.014 mmol cyanide groups) at 60 °C and 1 MPa in 24 h. The successful conversion of ECH and resolving shortcomings of the catalytic procedure led us to perform cycloaddition reactions under optimized conditions using catalyst 2 for all other epoxides and the obtained results are presented in Table 4 . Propylene oxide (PO) and epoxy butane (EB) was transformed to the corresponding carbonate with relatively high conversion rates of 87 and 68 %, respectively. In the case of bulky substrates like cyclohexene oxide (CHO) and styrene oxide (SO), in spite of the previously reported low yields [19–21] due to the high steric hindrance on the β-carbon of the substrate, which resulted in diminishing the reactivity, remarkable conversion rates were afforded with 100 % selectivity toward the corresponding carbonates (92 and 63, respectively). Moreover, for phenyl glycidyl ether (PGE) and allyl glycidyl ether (AGE), unlike the increment in the chain length of the substrates, promising results were obtained (61 and 92 %, respectively). Notably, no products were detected without the presence of the catalyst. 3.4 Proposed mechanism for CO2 fixation According to the previous literature reports [22,23], the existence of both basic and acidic sites is indispensable in promoting the reaction. With this in mind, the possible mechanism for the chemical transformation of carbon dioxide with epoxide into cyclic carbonate is explained in scheme 2 . Accordingly, the activation of epoxides occurs by adjacency to the sites of Lewis acid, whereas the nucleophilic attack of basic sites polarizes CO2 molecules, simultaneously (Scheme 2, route A). The formed oxygen anion of the activated CO2 molecule engages in a nucleophilic attack on the less sterically hindered carbon atom of epoxides to open the epoxy ring (Scheme 2, route B). This is followed by the insertion of carbon dioxide molecules, leading to the formation of alkyl carbonate anions (Scheme 2, route C). Finally, the corresponding carbonates are generated via intramolecular ring closure and in meantime, the catalyst is reformed (Scheme 2, route D). Overall, the concurrent existence of basic and Lewis acid sites facilitates the catalysis process. 3.5 Comparison of the catalytic activity of the prepared materials Cycloaddition reactions were accomplished in the existence of three catalysts with diverse cyanide functional groups to investigate the role of the functional groups in the progress of the reaction. The reaction conditions were optimized for each catalyst separately and similar optimal conditions (25 mg of catalyst (0.014 mmol cyanide groups), 60 °C, 1 MPa, and 24 h) were obtained for each of them. The best catalytic performance trends were shown by catalysts 2, 3, and 4, respectively. Catalyst 2 depicted the best results due to the multiplicity of its basic centers leading to an enhancement in the nucleophilic attack following by the better performance in reaction. In the comparison of catalysts 3 and 4, despite the long distance between two cyanide functional groups in 3 compared to that in 4 and hampering the nucleophilic attack, better results were observed for 3 due to the less free rotation of the cyanide group. Therefore, catalyst 4 is the least efficacious owing to the presence of free rotation of cyanide groups precluding nucleophilic attack at the β-carbon of the epoxides and progress of the reaction. Additionally, the CO2 gas sorption measurement helps to gain a better insight into the trend of the reaction process using the aforementioned catalysts. According to Fig. 3, catalyst 2 has the most tendency toward the adsorption of CO2. Therefore, more CO2 is adsorbed into the cyanide groups followed by increased nucleophilic attack and catalytic performance, which is in accordance with the greater catalytic performance of 2. Moreover, the amount of adsorbed CO2 for 3 is more than that of 4, resulting in the increased catalytic activity of 3 compared with 4. For a better understanding of the catalytic performance of the prepared materials, a comparison was made between our synthesized catalyst and other previously reported heterogeneous catalysts, and the results are exhibited in Table 5 . Accordingly, our catalysts revealed higher catalytic performance and TON and TOF in comparison with the reported MOF catalysts representing the superiority of our catalysts in the formation of cyclic carbonate. Additionally, the recycling capability of the catalysts was also evaluated. The prepared catalysts fictionalized as recyclable catalysts for the chemical transformation of CO2 (Fig. S10). The retention of major diffraction peaks in PXRD pattern compared to the pristine MOFs demonstrates that the crystallinity of the recycled MOFs is maintained after 4 sequential cycles (Fig. S11). FT-IR spectra also affirmed the structural crystallinity of the recycled structures (Fig. S12). In addition, N2 adsorption-desorption was conducted after each catalytic cycle and the obtained results are presented in Table S2. Inspired by the results, the value of surface area decreased slightly after each cycle which causes a very low relative decrease in the performance of the catalyst. Overall, the porosity of the structure is retained after catalytic cycles. On the other hand, CHN analysis was performed after each catalytic cycle in the reusability test and no obvious changes were seen in the amount of cyanide groups in MOFs which indicates that the amount of cyanide groups remains constant for recycled catalysts. Moreover, to affirm that the incorporated groups play the key role in the reaction progression and the reaction wouldn’t proceed in the presence of the sole framework without co-catalyst addition, CO2 fixation reactions were carried out in the presence of 1. The results indicate no significant conversion in the reaction progression. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we reported a strategy for the incorporation of various cyanide groups within an unsaturated Cr-based MOF, MIL-100-Cr. The prepared materials were utilized as heterogeneous catalysts for efficient transformation of epoxides to five-membered cyclic carbonate under mild solvent and co-catalyst free conditions. This is the first report utilizing cyanide functional groups to prevent the co-catalyst addition. The concomitant presence of cyanide groups and unsaturated chromium and as basic and Lewis acid site, respectively, resulted in the high catalytic performance of the synthesized materials. Likewise, the desired catalysts revealed outstanding results and TON for small epoxides as well as bulky and large ones. Meanwhile, the high tendency of prepared materials toward carbon dioxide adsorption speeds-up the nucleophilic attack at the β-carbon of the epoxides causing a remarkable enhancement in the catalytic performance of the materials. The catalysts have the potential to be recycled for five consecutive cycles without structural decomposition and considerable loss of catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: In the present work, a strategy for the incorporation of nitrogen-rich units to an unsaturated Cr-based MOF, MIL-100-Cr, is reported. Based on this strategy, various cyanide functional groups (diamino malononitrile, 1,3-phenylene diacetonitrile, and malononitrile) were incorporated into the framework and utilized as exceptional catalysts in the carbon dioxide fixation under mild, solvent, and co-catalyst free conditions. This is the first report on the application of cyano-bifunctional frameworks in cycloaddition reaction. The contemporaneous presence of accessible Lewis acid sites and pendent cyanide groups results in highly striking conversion and TON even for bulky and large substrates. High tendency and strong interaction of cyanide groups with CO2 cause a synergetic effect in the performance of the catalysts. The role of different cyanide groups applied in this work has also been studied. The reaction wouldn’t proceed in the presence of pristine MOF without co-catalyst addition.
coredata.dc:title: Cyano-bifunctional MOFs as superior catalysts for carbon dioxide fixation under co-catalyst and solvent free conditions
